Yes, there has been research conducted on the impact of climate change on fish populations in Lake Huron.

One of the most significant effects of climate change in the region is the warming of the water in Lake Huron. Warmer water temperatures can lead to changes in the distribution and abundance of fish species.

For example, some studies suggest that the warmer water temperatures in Lake Huron may favor fish species that prefer warmer waters, such as smallmouth bass, over other species that prefer cooler waters, such as lake trout. Additionally, warmer waters can have impacts on fish reproduction and growth, and may also affect food availability for fish species.

Climate change can also have impacts on fish populations indirectly, through changes to the ecosystem as a whole. For example, the introduction of invasive species and changes to water quality can have significant effects on fish populations.

Overall, climate change poses significant challenges for the management and conservation of fish populations in Lake Huron. Monitoring and responding to these changes will require ongoing research and management efforts, including sustainable fishing practices, the control of invasive species, and efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to minimize the impacts of climate change on fish populations.
